definitions.definition: Of, relating to, used in, or resulting from surgery.
Precise or very accurate.
definitions.example: The building was destroyed with a surgical air-strike.

definitions.definition: Class; kind.
(grammar) A division of nouns and pronouns (and sometimes of other parts of speech) into masculine or feminine, and sometimes other categories like neuter or common, and animate or inanimate.
(now sometimes proscribed) Sex (a category such as "male" or "female" into which sexually-reproducing organisms are divided on the basis of their reproductive roles in their species).
definitions.example: The effect of the medication is dependent upon age, gender, and other factors.

definitions.definition: Identification as a man, a woman or something else, and association with a (social) role or set of behavioral and cultural traits, clothing, etc; a category to which a person belongs on this basis. (Compare gender role, gender identity.)

(hardware) The quality which distinguishes connectors, which may be male (fitting into another connector) and female (having another connector fit into it), or genderless/androgynous (capable of fitting together with another connector of the same type).
To assign a gender to (a person); to perceive as having a gender; to address using terms (pronouns, nouns, adjectives...) that express a certain gender.
To perceive (a thing) as having characteristics associated with a certain gender, or as having been authored by someone of a certain gender.
Sound uttered by the mouth, especially by human beings in speech or song; sound thus uttered considered as possessing some special quality or character
definitions.example: His low voice allowed him to become a bass in the choir.

definitions.definition: Sound made through vibration of the vocal cords; sonant, or intonated, utterance; tone; — distinguished from mere breath sound as heard in whispering and voiceless consonants.
The tone or sound emitted by an object
The faculty or power of utterance
definitions.example: to cultivate the voice

definitions.definition: That which is communicated; message; meaning.
An expressed opinion, choice, will, desire, or wish; the right or ability to make such expression or to have it considered
Command; precept.
One who speaks; a speaker.
A particular style or way of writing that expresses a certain tone or feeling.

(grammar) A particular way of inflecting or conjugating verbs, or a particular form of a verb, by means of which is indicated the relation of the subject of the verb to the action which the verb expresses.
definitions.example: The verbal system of Latin has two voices, active and passive.

definitions.definition: In harmony, an independent vocal or instrumental part in a piece of composition.
definitions.example: The theme of this piece constantly migrates between the three voice parts.

definitions.definition: (IRC) A flag associated with a user on a channel, determining whether or not they can send messages to the channel.
To engender.
To breed.
A person who is in adolescence; someone who has reached puberty but is not yet an adult.
Of, relating to, or at the age of adolescence; at the stage between being a child and an adult
To admit to the truth, particularly in the context of sins or crimes committed.
definitions.example: I confess to spray-painting all over that mural!

definitions.definition: To acknowledge faith in; to profess belief in.
To unburden (oneself) of sins to God or a priest, in order to receive absolution.
To hear or receive such a confession of sins from.
To disclose or reveal.
Characterized by the creation of new ideas or inventions.
Forward-looking; ahead of current thinking.
An incident of bleeding, as in haemophilia.
A narrow edge around a page layout, to be printed but cut off afterwards (added to allow for slight misalignment, especially with pictures that should run to the edge of the finished sheet).
(sound recording) The situation where sound is picked up by a microphone from a source other than that which is intended.
The removal of air bubbles from a pipe containing other fluids.
(of a person or animal) To lose blood through an injured blood vessel.
definitions.example: If her nose bleeds, try to use ice.

definitions.definition: To let or draw blood from.
To take large amounts of money from.
To steadily lose (something vital).
definitions.example: The company was bleeding talent.

definitions.definition: (of an ink or dye) To spread from the intended location and stain the surrounding cloth or paper.
definitions.example: Ink traps counteract bleeding.

definitions.definition: To remove air bubbles from a pipe containing other fluids.
To bleed on; to make bloody.
To show one's group loyalty by showing (its associated color) in one's blood.
definitions.example: He was a devoted Vikings fan: he bled purple.

definitions.definition: To lose sap, gum, or juice.
definitions.example: A tree or a vine bleeds when tapped or wounded.

definitions.definition: To issue forth, or drop, like blood from an incision.
(of a phonological rule) To destroy the environment where another phonological rule would have applied.
definitions.example: Labialization bleeds palatalization.

definitions.definition: A person who owns and rents land such as a house, apartment, or condo.
The owner or manager of a public house.
(with "the") A shark, imagined as the owner of the surf to be avoided.
The process of thinking or meditating on a subject.
The act or process of reasoning a priori from premises given or assumed.
A conclusion to which the mind comes by speculating; mere theory; notion; conjecture.
An investment involving higher-than-normal risk in order to obtain a higher-than-normal return.

The act or practice of buying land, goods, shares, etc., in expectation of selling at a higher price, or of selling with the expectation of repurchasing at a lower price; a trading on anticipated fluctuations in price, as distinguished from trading in which the profit expected is the difference between the retail and wholesale prices, or the difference of price in different markets.
Examination by the eye; view.
Power of sight.
A card game in which the players buy from one another trumps or whole hands, upon a chance of getting the highest trump dealt, which entitles the holder to the pool of stakes.
The process of anticipating which branch of code will be chosen and executing it in advance.
A list or invoice of the passengers or goods being carried by a commercial vehicle or ship.
A file containing metadata describing other files.
A public declaration; an open statement; a manifesto.
To show plainly; to make to appear distinctly, usually to the mind; to put beyond question or doubt; to display; to exhibit.
definitions.example: His courage manifested itself through the look on his face.

definitions.definition: To exhibit the manifests or prepared invoices of; to declare at the customhouse.
Evident to the senses, especially to the sight; apparent; distinctly perceived.
Obvious to the understanding; apparent to the mind; easily apprehensible; plain; not obscure or hidden.
(used with "of") Detected; convicted.
The act of moving or revolving around, or as in a circle or orbit; a revolution
The circumference of, or distance around, any space; the measure of a line around an area.
That which encircles anything, as a ring or crown.
The space enclosed within a circle, or within limits.
Enclosed path of an electric current, usually designed for a certain function.
A regular or appointed trip from place to place as part of one's job
The jurisdiction of certain judges within a state or country, whether itinerant or not.
Various administrative divisions of imperial and early Republican China, including:
Methodism: The basic grouping of local Methodist churches.
By analogy to the proceeding three, a set of theaters among which the same acts circulate; especially common in the heyday of vaudeville.
A track on which a race in held; a racetrack
Circumlocution
A thought that unconsciously goes round and round in a person's mind and controls that person.
A closed path, without repeated vertices allowed
To move in a circle; to go round; to circulate.
To travel around.
definitions.example: Having circuited the air.

definitions.definition: A court that sits at more than one location in the district that it serves.
One who speaks as the voice of a group of people.
The act or an instance of receding or withdrawing.
A period of reduced economic activity
The ceremonial filing out of clergy and/or choir at the end of a church service.
The act of ceding something back.
The selection of one thing or person over others (with the main adposition being "for" in relation to the thing or person, but possibly also "of")
definitions.example: He has a preference for crisp wines.

definitions.definition: The option to so select, and the one selected.
definitions.example: Can I keep my preferences when I upgrade to the new version of this application?

definitions.definition: The state of being preferred over others.
A strong liking or personal valuation.
A preferential bias; partiality; discrimination.
To give preferential treatment to; to give a preference to.
Preferans, a card game, principally played in Eastern Europe.
A higher than normal body temperature of a person (or, generally, a mammal), usually caused by disease.
definitions.example: "I have a fever. I think I've the flu."

definitions.definition: (usually in combination with one or more preceding words) Any of various diseases.
A state of excitement or anxiety.
A group of stingrays.
To put into a fever; to affect with fever.
definitions.example: a fevered lip

definitions.definition: To become fevered.
An approval, by an authority, generally one that makes something valid.
definitions.example: The whalers had been operating in the contested waters off the island with sanction from the Japanese government.

definitions.definition: A penalty, punishment, or some coercive measure, intended to ensure compliance; especially one adopted by several nations, or by an international body.
definitions.example: The United States enacted a new round of sanctions against the apartheid regime of South Africa.

definitions.definition: A law, treaty, or contract, or a clause within a law, treaty, or contract, specifying any of the above.
To ratify; to make valid.
To give official authorization or approval to; to countenance.
To penalize (a State etc.) with sanctions.
To bar (someone) from entering; to keep out.
To expel; to put out.
definitions.example: to exclude young animals from the womb or from eggs

definitions.definition: To omit from consideration.
definitions.example: Count from 1 to 30, but exclude the prime numbers.

definitions.definition: To refuse to accept (evidence) as valid.
To eliminate from diagnostic consideration.
An image, symbol, picture, or other representation usually as an object of religious devotion.
(especially Eastern Christianity) A type of religious painting portraying a saint or scene from Scripture, often done on wooden panels.
(by extension) A person or thing that is the best example of a certain profession or some doing.
definitions.example: That man is an icon in the business; he personifies loyalty and good business sense.

definitions.definition: A small picture that represents something (such as an icon on a computer screen which when clicked performs some function.)
A word, character, or sign whose form reflects and is determined by the referent; onomatopoeic words are necessarily all icons.
In civil law, a case where two or more people disagree and one or more of the parties take the case to a court for resolution.
definitions.example: The lawyer advised his client against filing a lawsuit as it would take a lot of time and money to resolve.

definitions.definition: A circumstance in which a choice must be made between two or more alternatives that seem equally undesirable.
A difficult circumstance or problem.
A type of syllogism of the form "if A is true then B is true; if C is true then D is true; either A or C is true; therefore either B or D is true".
Offering to an opponent a choice between two (equally unfavorable) alternatives.
A mechanism which can be used to hold a note, as the right pedal on a piano.
To maintain, or keep in existence.
definitions.example: The city came under sustained attack by enemy forces.

definitions.definition: To provide for or nourish.
definitions.example: provisions to sustain an army

definitions.definition: To encourage or sanction (something).
To experience or suffer (an injury, etc.).
definitions.example: The building sustained major damage in the earthquake.

definitions.definition: To confirm, prove, or corroborate; to uphold.
definitions.example: to sustain a charge, an accusation, or a proposition

definitions.definition: To keep from falling; to bear; to uphold; to support.
definitions.example: A foundation sustains the superstructure; an animal sustains a load; a rope sustains a weight.

definitions.definition: To aid, comfort, or relieve; to vindicate.
The waging of war or armed conflict against an enemy.
Military operations of some particular kind e.g. guerrilla warfare.
To lead a military life; to carry on continual wars.
Once every year without fail, yearly
A strong wind.
definitions.example: We're having a bit of a blow this afternoon.

definitions.definition: A chance to catch one’s breath.
definitions.example: The players were able to get a blow during the last timeout.

definitions.definition: Cocaine.
Cannabis.
(US Chicago Regional) Heroin.
To produce an air current.
To propel by an air current.
definitions.example: Blow the dust off that book and open it up.

definitions.definition: To be propelled by an air current.
definitions.example: The leaves blow through the streets in the fall.

definitions.definition: To create or shape by blowing; as in to blow bubbles, to blow glass.
To force a current of air upon with the mouth, or by other means.
definitions.example: to blow the fire

definitions.definition: To clear of contents by forcing air through.
definitions.example: to blow an egg

definitions.definition: To cause to make sound by blowing, as a musical instrument.
To make a sound as the result of being blown.
definitions.example: In the harbor, the ships' horns blew.

definitions.definition: (of a cetacean) To exhale visibly through the spout the seawater which it has taken in while feeding.
definitions.example: There she blows! (i.e. "I see a whale spouting!")

definitions.definition: To explode.
definitions.example: Get away from that burning gas tank! It's about to blow!

definitions.definition: (with "up" or with prep phrase headed by "to") To cause to explode, shatter, or be utterly destroyed.
definitions.example: The aerosol can was blown to bits.

definitions.definition: To cause sudden destruction of.
definitions.example: He blew the tires and the engine.

definitions.definition: To suddenly fail destructively.
definitions.example: He tried to sprint, but his ligaments blew and he was barely able to walk to the finish line.

definitions.definition: (used to express displeasure or frustration) Damn.
To be very undesirable. (See also suck.)
definitions.example: This blows!

definitions.definition: To recklessly squander.
definitions.example: I blew $35 thou on a car.

definitions.definition: To fellate; to perform oral sex on (usually a man)
definitions.example: Who did you have to blow to get those backstage passes?

definitions.definition: To leave, especially suddenly or in a hurry.
definitions.example: Let's blow this joint.

definitions.definition: To make flyblown, to defile, especially with fly eggs.
To spread by report; to publish; to disclose.
To inflate, as with pride; to puff up.
To breathe hard or quick; to pant; to puff.
To put out of breath; to cause to blow from fatigue.
definitions.example: to blow a horse

definitions.definition: To talk loudly; to boast; to storm.
To sing.
definitions.example: That girl has a wonderful voice; just listen to her blow!

definitions.definition: To leave the Church of Scientology in an unauthorized manner.
Blue.
The act of striking or hitting.
definitions.example: A fabricator is used to direct a sharp blow to the surface of the stone.

definitions.definition: A sudden or forcible act or effort; an assault.
A damaging occurrence.
definitions.example: A further blow to the group came in 1917 when Thomson died while canoeing in Algonquin Park.

definitions.definition: A mass or display of flowers; a yield.
A display of anything brilliant or bright.
A bloom, state of flowering.
definitions.example: Roses in full blow.

definitions.definition: To blossom; to cause to bloom or blossom.
One who operates.
A telecommunications facilitator whose job is to establish temporary network connections.
A function or other mapping that carries variables defined on a domain into another variable or set of variables in a defined range.
The game of Chinese whispers.
A person who is adept at making deals or getting results, especially one who uses questionable methods.
A member of a military special operations unit.
The administrator of a channel or network on IRC.
A symbol that represents a construct in a programming language and differs from a normal function in its syntax.
A kind of expression that enters into an a-bar movement dependency and is said to bind a variable.
definitions.example: In the sentence "What did Bill say he wants to buy?", "what" is an operator, binding a phonetically empty variable.

definitions.definition: A boy or young man.
A Jack the lad; a boyo.
definitions.example: I think he reckons he's a bit of a lad.

definitions.definition: A familiar term of address for a young man.
definitions.example: Come here, lad, and help me shift these boxes.

definitions.definition: A groom who works with horses (also called stable-lad).
The penis.
An emergency vehicle designed for transporting seriously ill or injured people to a hospital.
A mobile field hospital.
A prairie wagon.
To transport by ambulance.
An expert in economics, especially one who studies economic data and extracts higher-level information or proposes theories.
One concerned with political economy.
One who manages a household.
One who economizes, or manages domestic or other concerns with frugality; one who expends money, time, or labor, judiciously, and without waste.
An edifice or building.
The act of constructing, construction, fabrication.
The structure of anything, the manner in which the parts of a thing are united; workmanship, texture, make.
definitions.example: cloth of a beautiful fabric

definitions.definition: The framework underlying a structure.
definitions.example: the fabric of our lives

definitions.definition: A material made of fibers, a textile or cloth.
definitions.example: cotton fabric

definitions.definition: The appearance of crystalline grains in a rock.
Interconnected nodes that look like a textile fabric when diagrammed.
definitions.example: The Internet is a fabric of computers connected by routers.

definitions.definition: Not bragging or boasting about oneself or one's achievements; unpretentious, humble.
Small, moderate in size.
definitions.example: He earns a modest amount of money.

definitions.definition: Pure and delicate from a sense of propriety.
definitions.example: modest thoughts or language

definitions.definition: (especially of behaviour or clothing) Intending to avoid the encouraging of sexual attraction in others.
To deliberately take hold of; to grab or capture.
To take advantage of (an opportunity or circumstance).
To take possession of (by force, law etc.).
definitions.example: to seize a ship after libeling

definitions.definition: To have a sudden and powerful effect upon.
definitions.example: a fever seized him

definitions.definition: To bind, lash or make fast, with several turns of small rope, cord, or small line.
definitions.example: to seize or stop one rope on to another

definitions.definition: To fasten, fix.
To lay hold in seizure, by hands or claws (+ on or upon).
definitions.example: to seize on the neck of a horse

definitions.definition: To have a seizure.
To bind or lock in position immovably; see also seize up.
definitions.example: Rust caused the engine to seize, never to run again.

definitions.definition: To submit for consideration to a deliberative body.
(with of) To cause (an action or matter) to be or remain before (a certain judge or court).
definitions.example: This Court will remain seized of this matter.

definitions.definition: An open area in a town housing a public market.
The space, actual or metaphorical, in which a market operates.
definitions.example: Some high-street retailers were slow to enter the new digital marketplace of the Internet.

definitions.definition: (by extension) The world of commerce and trade.
A place or sphere for the exchange of anything, such as ideas or fashions.
In psychotherapy and psychiatry, a state of mind producing serious, long-term lowering of enjoyment of life or inability to visualize a happy future.
definitions.example: I used to suffer from depression, but now I'm mostly content with my life.

definitions.definition: An area that is lower in topography than its surroundings.
In psychotherapy and psychiatry, a period of unhappiness or low morale which lasts longer than several weeks and may include ideation of self-inflicted injury or suicide.
An area of lowered air pressure that generally brings moist weather, sometimes promoting hurricanes and tornadoes.
A period of major economic contraction.
Four consecutive quarters of negative, real GDP growth. See NBER.
definitions.example: The Great Depression was the worst financial event in US history.

definitions.definition: The act of lowering or pressing something down.
definitions.example: Depression of the lever starts the machine.

definitions.definition: A lowering, in particular a reduction in a particular biological variable or the function of an organ, in contrast to elevation.
Born or originating in, native to a land or region, especially before an intrusion.
Innate, inborn.
A person or party that is consulted
A person whose occupation is to be consulted for their expertise, advice, or help in an area or specialty; a party whose business is to be similarly consulted
Something that protects.
A condom.
Serving, intended or wishing to protect
definitions.example: Mother bears are famously protective of their cubs.

definitions.definition: A piece of cloth, or other suitable material, sewed or otherwise fixed upon a garment to repair or strengthen it, especially upon an old garment to cover a hole.
definitions.example: His sleeves had patches on the elbows where different fabric had been sewn on to replace material that had worn away.

definitions.definition: A small piece of anything used to repair damage or a breach; as, a patch on a kettle, a roof, etc.
definitions.example: I can't afford to replace the roof, which is what it really needs. I'll have the roofer apply a patch.

definitions.definition: A piece of any size, used to repair something for a temporary period only, or that it is temporary because it is not meant to last long or will be removed as soon as a proper repair can be made, which will happen in the near future.
definitions.example: "This patch should hold until you reach the city," the mechanic said as he patted the car's hood.

definitions.definition: A small, usually contrasting but always somehow different or distinct, part of something else (location, time, size)
definitions.example: Doesn't that patch of clouds looks like a bunny?

definitions.definition: (specifically) A small area, a small plot of land or piece of ground.
definitions.example: Scattered patches of trees or growing corn.

definitions.definition: A local region of professional responsibility.
A small piece of black silk stuck on the face or neck to heighten beauty by contrast, worn by ladies in the 17th and 18th centuries; an imitation beauty mark.
A piece of material used to cover a wound.
An adhesive piece of material, impregnated with a drug, which is worn on the skin, the drug being slowly absorbed over a period of time.
definitions.example: Many people use a nicotine patch to wean themselves off of nicotine.

definitions.definition: A cover worn over a damaged eye, an eyepatch.
definitions.example: He had scratched his cornea so badly that his doctor told him to wear a patch.

definitions.definition: A block on the muzzle of a gun, to do away with the effect of dispart, in sighting.
A patch file, a file that describes changes to be made to a computer file or files, usually changes made to a computer program that fix a programming bug.
A small piece of material that is manually passed through a gun barrel to clean it.
A piece of greased cloth or leather used as wrapping for a rifle ball, to make it fit the bore.
(often patch cable, patch cord etc.; see also patch panel) A cable connecting two pieces of electrical equipment.
A sound setting for a musical synthesizer (originally selected by means of a patch cable).
An overlay used to obtain a stronger impression.
To mend by sewing on a piece or pieces of cloth, leather, or the like
definitions.example: My coat needs patching.

definitions.definition: To mend with pieces; to repair by fastening pieces on.
To make out of pieces or patches, like a quilt.
To join or unite the pieces of; to patch the skirt.
To employ a temporary, removable electronic connection, as one between two components in a communications system.
(generally with the particle "up") To repair or arrange in a hasty or clumsy manner
definitions.example: The truce between the two countries has been patched up.

definitions.definition: To make the changes a patch describes; to apply a patch to the files in question. Hence:
To connect two pieces of electrical equipment using a cable.
definitions.example: I'll need to patch the preamp output to the mixer.

definitions.definition: A paltry fellow; a rogue; a ninny; a fool.
To think, meditate or reflect on a subject; to consider, to deliberate or cogitate.
To make an inference based on inconclusive evidence; to surmise or conjecture.
To make a risky trade in the hope of making a profit; to venture or gamble.
To anticipate which branch of code will be chosen and execute it in advance.
A time period of indeterminate length, generally more than one year.
A unit of time, smaller than eons and greater than periods.
A flag or standard used by a military commander, monarch or nation.
(by extension) The military unit under such a flag or standard.
(by extension) A military or administrative subdivision.
Any large sign, especially when made of soft material or fabric.
definitions.example: The mayor hung a banner across Main Street to commemorate the town's 100th anniversary.

definitions.definition: A large piece of cloth with a slogan, motto, or emblem carried in a demonstration or other procession or suspended in some conspicuous place.
(by extension) A cause or purpose; a campaign or movement.
definitions.example: They usually make their case under the banner of environmentalism.

definitions.definition: The title of a newspaper as printed on its front page; the nameplate; masthead.
A type of advertisement on a web page or on television, usually taking the form of a graphic or animation above or alongside the content.
The principal standard of a knight.
A type of administrative division in Inner Mongolia, China (хошуу/旗) and Tuva (кожуун), made during the Qing dynasty. At this time, Outer Mongolia and part of Xinjiang were also divided this way.
To adorn with a banner.
To display as a banner headline.
Exceptional; very good.
One who bans something.
To deal effectively with something, especially if difficult.
definitions.example: I thought I would never be able to cope with life after the amputation, but I have learned how to be happy again.

definitions.definition: To cut and form a mitred joint in wood or metal.
To clip the beak or talons of a bird.
A long, loose cloak worn by a priest, deacon, or bishop when presiding over a ceremony other than the Mass.
Any covering such as a canopy or a mantle.
The vault or canopy of the skies, heavens etc.
A covering piece on top of a wall exposed to the weather, usually made of metal, masonry, or stone, and sloped to carry off water.
(foundry) The top part of a sand casting mold.
An ancient tribute due to the lord of the soil, out of the lead mines in Derbyshire, England.
To cover (a joint or structure) with coping.
To form a cope or arch; to bend or arch; to bow.
To bargain for; to buy.
To exchange or barter.
To make return for; to requite; to repay.
To match oneself against; to meet; to encounter.
To encounter; to meet; to have to do with.
The amount of money taken as sales transacted in a given period.
definitions.example: The company had an annual turnover of $500,000.

definitions.definition: The frequency with which stock is replaced after being used or sold, workers leave and are replaced, a property changes hands, etc.
definitions.example: High staff-turnover can lead to low morale amongst employees

definitions.definition: A semicircular pastry made by turning one half of a circular crust over the other, enclosing the filling (usually fruit).
definitions.example: They only served me one apple turnover for breakfast.

definitions.definition: A loss of possession of the ball without scoring.
definitions.example: The Nimrods committed another dismaying turnover en route to another humiliating loss.

definitions.definition: A measure of leg speed: the frequency with which one takes strides when running, typically given in strides per minute.
The act or result of overturning something; an upset.
definitions.example: a bad turnover in a carriage

definitions.definition: An apprentice, in any trade, who is handed over from one master to another to complete his time.
Capable of being turned over; designed to be turned over.
definitions.example: a turnover collar

definitions.definition: Tropæum.
An object, usually in the form of a statuette, cup, or shield, awarded for success in a competition or to mark a special achievement.
definitions.example: He won the trophy in a running competition.

definitions.definition: An object taken as a prize by a hunter or conqueror, especially one that is displayed.
definitions.example: The set of antlers which hung on the wall was his prized trophy.

definitions.definition: Any emblem of success; a status symbol.
definitions.example: His trophies included his second wife, his successful children, the third and fourth homes in Palm Beach and Malibu, his three yachts (for the Pacific, the Atlantic, and the Mediterranean), his jet, and his mistresses.

definitions.definition: (by extension) An object taken by a serial killer or rapist as a memento of the crime.

A display of weaponry and other militaria, often captured from a defeated enemy, as an ornament designed for the purpose of triumphalist display by a victor or as a show of military prowess by a monarch.
The act of resisting, or the capacity to resist.
definitions.example: the resistance of bacteria to certain antibiotics

definitions.definition: A force that tends to oppose motion.
Electrical resistance.
An underground organisation engaged in a struggle for liberation from forceful occupation; a resistance movement.

A bag; especially a large bag of strong, coarse material for storage and handling of various commodities, such as potatoes, coal, coffee; or, a bag with handles used at a supermarket, a grocery sack; or, a small bag for small items, a satchel.

The amount a sack holds; also, an archaic or historical measure of varying capacity, depending on commodity type and according to local usage; an old English measure of weight, usually of wool, equal to 13 stone (182 pounds), or in other sources, 26 stone (364 pounds).
definitions.example: The American sack of salt is 215 pounds; the sack of wheat, two bushels. — McElrath.

definitions.definition: The plunder and pillaging of a captured town or city.
definitions.example: The sack of Rome.

definitions.definition: Loot or booty obtained by pillage.
A successful tackle of the quarterback behind the line of scrimmage. See verb sense4 below.
One of the square bases anchored at first base, second base, or third base.
definitions.example: He twisted his ankle sliding into the sack at second.

definitions.definition: Dismissal from employment, or discharge from a position, usually as give (someone) the sack or get the sack. See verb sense5 below.
definitions.example: He got the sack for being late all the time.

definitions.definition: Bed; usually as hit the sack or in the sack. See also sack out.

(also sacque) A kind of loose-fitting gown or dress with sleeves which hangs from the shoulders, such as a gown with a Watteau back or sack-back, fashionable in the late 17th to 18th century; or, formerly, a loose-fitting hip-length jacket, cloak or cape.
A sack coat; a kind of coat worn by men, and extending from top to bottom without a cross seam.
The scrotum.
definitions.example: He got passed the ball, but it hit him in the sack.

definitions.definition: To put in a sack or sacks.
definitions.example: Help me sack the groceries.

definitions.definition: To bear or carry in a sack upon the back or the shoulders.
To plunder or pillage, especially after capture; to obtain spoils of war from.
definitions.example: The barbarians sacked Rome.

definitions.definition: To tackle the quarterback behind the line of scrimmage, especially before he is able to throw a pass.
To discharge from a job or position; to fire.
definitions.example: He was sacked last September.

definitions.definition: In the phrase sack out, to fall asleep. See also hit the sack.
definitions.example: The kids all sacked out before 9:00 on New Year’s Eve.

definitions.definition: A variety of light-colored dry wine from Spain or the Canary Islands; also, any strong white wine from southern Europe; sherry.
A bag or pouch inside a plant or animal that typically contains a fluid.
(games) A sacrifice.
definitions.example: Kasparov's queen sac early in the game gained him a positional advantage against Kramnik.

definitions.definition: The privilege, formerly enjoyed by the lord of a manor, of holding courts, trying causes, and imposing fines.
A bag or pouch inside a plant or animal that typically contains a fluid.
(games) A sacrifice.
definitions.example: Kasparov's queen sac early in the game gained him a positional advantage against Kramnik.

definitions.definition: (games) To sacrifice.
definitions.example: I kept saccing monsters at the altar until I was rewarded with a new weapon.

definitions.definition: The privilege, formerly enjoyed by the lord of a manor, of holding courts, trying causes, and imposing fines.
The periodic change of the sea level, particularly when caused by the gravitational influence of the sun and the moon.
A stream, current or flood.
(chronology, except in liturgy) Time, notably anniversary, period or season linked to an ecclesiastical feast.
A time.
definitions.example: The doctor's no good this tide.

definitions.definition: A point or period of time identified or described by a qualifier (found in compounds).
definitions.example: Eventide, noontide, morrowtide, nighttide, moon-tide, harvest-tide, wintertide, summertide, springtide, autumn-tide etc.,.

definitions.definition: The period of twelve hours.
Something which changes like the tides of the sea.
Tendency or direction of causes, influences, or events; course; current.
Violent confluence
To cause to float with the tide; to drive or carry with the tide or stream.
To pour a tide or flood.
definitions.example: The ocean tided most impressively.

definitions.definition: To work into or out of a river or harbor by drifting with the tide and anchoring when it becomes adverse.
To happen, occur.
A permit to enter and leave a country, normally issued by the authorities of the country to be visited.
To endorse (a passport, etc.).
An obsessive fan, a superfan
A writer of tragedy.
A tragedy; a tragic drama.
Causing great sadness or suffering.
Relating to tragedy in a literary work.
(in tabloid newspapers) Having been the victim of a tragedy.
definitions.example: 2008, Search for tragic Madeleine McCann over (in The Daily Telegraph of Australia, 14 February 2008) http//www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/search-for-maddie-over/story-e6freuy9-1111115550129

definitions.definition: Any of numerous large, complex naturally-produced molecules composed of one or more long chains of amino acids, in which the amino acid groups are held together by peptide bonds.
(nutrition) One of three major classes of food or source of food energy (4 kcal/gram) abundant in animal-derived foods (i.e. meat) and some vegetables, such as legumes.
(nutrition) A food rich in protein, often a meat or meat substitute.
One who renders account; one accountable.
A reckoner, or someone who maintains financial matters for a person(s).
One who is skilled in, keeps, or adjusts, accounts; an officer in a public office, who has charge of the accounts.
One whose profession includes organizing, maintaining and auditing the records of another. The records are usually, but not always, financial records.
Accountable.
Of or relating to theory; abstract; not empirical.
Someone who analyzes.
A mathematician who studies real analysis.
A systems analyst.
A practitioner of psychoanalysis.
A financial analyst; a business analyst.
Any raised flat surface that can be walked on: a balcony; a porch; a raised patio; a flat rooftop.
The floorlike covering of the horizontal sections, or compartments, of a ship. Small vessels have only one deck; larger ships have two or three decks.
definitions.example: to swab the deck

definitions.definition: A main aeroplane surface, especially of a biplane or multiplane.
A pack or set of playing cards.
(by extension) A set of cards owned by each individual player and from which they draw when playing.
A set of slides for a presentation.
A heap or store.
A folded paper used for distributing illicit drugs.
The floor.
definitions.example: We hit the deck as bullets began to fly.

definitions.definition: To furnish with a deck, as a vessel.
To knock someone to the floor, especially with a single punch.
definitions.example: Wow, did you see her deck that guy who pinched her?

definitions.definition: To cause a player to run out of cards to draw and usually lose the game as a result.
(sometimes with out) To dress (someone) up, to clothe with more than ordinary elegance
(sometimes with out) To decorate (something).
To cover; to overspread.
Relenting; forbearance to cause or allow harm to another.
definitions.example: She took mercy on him and quit embarrassing him.

definitions.definition: Forgiveness or compassion, especially toward those less fortunate.
definitions.example: Have mercy on the poor and assist them if you can.

definitions.definition: A tendency toward forgiveness, pity, or compassion.
definitions.example: Mercy is one of his many virtues.

definitions.definition: Instances of forbearance or forgiveness.
definitions.example: Psalms 40:11 Do not withhold Your tender mercies from me, O Lord

definitions.definition: A blessing; something to be thankful for.
definitions.example: It was a mercy that we were not inside when the roof collapsed

definitions.definition: To feel mercy
To show mercy; to pardon or treat leniently because of mercy
Expressing surprise or alarm.
definitions.example: Mercy! Look at the state of you!

definitions.definition: A soldier, normally a member of a marine corps, trained to serve on board or from a ship
definitions.example: He was a marine in World War II.

definitions.definition: Capitalised in the plural A marine corps.
definitions.example: He fought with the Marines in World War II.

definitions.definition: A painting representing some marine subject.
Belonging to or characteristic of the sea; existing or found in the sea; formed or produced by the sea.
Relating to or connected with the sea (in operation, scope, etc.), especially as pertains to shipping, a navy, or naval forces.
Used or adapted for use at sea.
Inhabiting the high seas; oceanic; pelagic. (distinguished from maritime or littoral)
Belonging to or situated at the seaside; maritime.
The act of prescribing a rule, law, etc..
definitions.example: "Jurisdiction to prescribe" is a state's authority to make its laws applicable to certain persons or activities. -- Richard G. Alexander, Iran and Libya Sanctions Act of 1996: Congress exceeds its jurisdiction to prescribe law. Washington and Lee Law Review, 1997.

definitions.definition: Also called extinctive prescription or liberative prescription. A time period within which a right must be exercised, otherwise it will be extinguished.

Also called acquisitive prescription. A time period after which a person who has, in the role of an owner, uninterruptedly, peacefully, and publicly possessed another's property acquires the property. The described process is known as acquisition by prescription and adverse possession.
A written order, as by a physician or nurse practitioner, for the administration of a medicine or other intervention. See also scrip.
definitions.example: The surgeon wrote a prescription for a pain killer and physical therapy.

definitions.definition: The prescription medicine or intervention so prescribed.
definitions.example: The pharmacist gave her a bottle containing her prescription.

definitions.definition: The formal description of the lens geometry needed for spectacles, etc..
definitions.example: The optician followed the optometrist's prescription for her new eyeglasses.

definitions.definition: The act or practice of laying down norms of language usage, as opposed to description, i.e. recording and describing actual usage.
An instance of a prescriptive pronouncement.
A plan or procedure to obtain a given end result; a recipe.
Circumscription; restraint; limitation.
(of a drug, etc.) only available with a physician or nurse practitioner's written prescription
definitions.example: Many powerful pain killers are prescription drugs in the U.S.

definitions.definition: Access to a resource for a period of time, generally for payment.
definitions.example: I have a monthly subscription to the Daily Telegraph newspaper.

definitions.definition: The formal acceptance of something, especially when verified with a signature.
The signing of one's name.
A person, group, or organization that uses violent action, or the threat of violent action, to further political goals.
An agent or partisan of the revolutionary tribunal during the Reign of Terror in France.
Of or relating to terrorism.
An appointment, especially to speak or perform.
definitions.example: The lecturer has three speaking engagements this week.

definitions.definition: Connection or attachment.
definitions.example: Check the gears for full engagement before turning the handle.

definitions.definition: (by extension, about human emotional state) The feeling of being compelled, drawn in, connected to what is happening, interested in what will happen next.
The period of time when marriage is planned or promised.
definitions.example: We are enjoying a long engagement, but haven't yet set a date.

definitions.definition: In any situation of conflict, an actual instance of active hostilities.
definitions.example: The engagement resulted in many casualties.

definitions.definition: The point at which the fencers are close enough to join blades, or to make an effective attack during an encounter.
definitions.example: After engagement it quickly became clear which of the fencers was going to prevail.

definitions.definition: Something that is rented.
definitions.example: It's just a rental, so I don't need to take very good care of it.

definitions.definition: The payment made to rent something.
A business that rents out something to its customers.
An act of renting.
A player traded to a team with a year or less on his contract
Relating to rent.
Relating to renting.
All animals or plants of the same species or subspecies.
definitions.example: a breed of animal

definitions.definition: A race or lineage; offspring or issue.
A group of people with shared characteristics.
definitions.example: People who were taught classical Greek and Latin at school are a dying breed.

definitions.definition: To produce offspring sexually; to bear young.
To give birth to; to be the native place of.
definitions.example: a pond breeds fish; a northern country breeds stout men

definitions.definition: Of animals, to mate.
To keep animals and have them reproduce in a way that improves the next generation’s qualities.
To arrange the mating of specific animals.
definitions.example: She wanted to breed her cow to the neighbor's registered bull.

definitions.definition: To propagate or grow plants trying to give them certain qualities.
definitions.example: He tries to breed blue roses.

definitions.definition: To take care of in infancy and through childhood; to bring up.
To yield or result in.
definitions.example: disaster breeds famine;  familiarity breeds contempt

definitions.definition: To be formed in the parent or dam; to be generated, or to grow, like young before birth.
(sometimes as breed up) To educate; to instruct; to bring up
To produce or obtain by any natural process.
To have birth; to be produced, developed or multiplied.
To ejaculate inside someone's ass
The act of burying; interment
The condition of being pregnant.
The period of time this condition prevails.
The progression of stages from conception to birth.
To tie; to confine by any ligature.
To cohere or stick together in a mass.
definitions.example: Just to make the cheese more binding

definitions.definition: To be restrained from motion, or from customary or natural action, as by friction.
definitions.example: I wish I knew why the sewing machine binds up after I use it for a while.

definitions.definition: To exert a binding or restraining influence.
definitions.example: These are the ties that bind.

definitions.definition: To tie or fasten tightly together, with a cord, band, ligature, chain, etc.
definitions.example: to bind grain in bundles  to bind a prisoner

definitions.definition: To confine, restrain, or hold by physical force or influence of any kind.
definitions.example: Frost binds the earth.

definitions.definition: To couple.
To oblige, restrain, or hold, by authority, law, duty, promise, vow, affection, or other social tie.
definitions.example: to bind the conscience  to bind by kindness  bound by affection  commerce binds nations to each other

definitions.definition: To put (a person) under definite legal obligations, especially, under the obligation of a bond or covenant.
To place under legal obligation to serve.
definitions.example: to bind an apprentice  bound out to service

definitions.definition: To protect or strengthen by applying a band or binding, as the edge of a carpet or garment.
To make fast (a thing) about or upon something, as by tying; to encircle with something.
definitions.example: to bind a belt about one  to bind a compress upon a wound

definitions.definition: To cover, as with a bandage.
definitions.example: to bind up a wound

definitions.definition: To prevent or restrain from customary or natural action, as by producing constipation.
definitions.example: Certain drugs bind the bowels.

definitions.definition: To put together in a cover, as of books.
definitions.example: The three novels were bound together.

definitions.definition: To make two or more elements stick together.
To associate an identifier with a value; to associate a variable name, method name, etc. with the content of a storage location.
To complain; to whine about something.
(with infinitive) Obliged (to).
definitions.example: You are not legally bound to reply.

definitions.definition: (of a morpheme) That cannot stand alone as a free word.
(of a variable) Constrained by a quantifier.
Constipated; costive.
Confined or restricted to a certain place; e.g. railbound.
Unable to move in certain conditions; e.g. snowbound.
Ready, prepared.
Ready to start or go (to); moving in the direction (of).
definitions.example: Is that message bound for me?

definitions.definition: (with infinitive) Very likely (to), certain to
definitions.example: They were bound to come into conflict eventually.

definitions.definition: (often used in plural) A boundary, the border which one must cross in order to enter or leave a territory.
definitions.example: I reached the northern bound of my property, took a deep breath and walked on.

definitions.definition: A value which is known to be greater or smaller than a given set of values.
To surround a territory or other geographical entity.
definitions.example: France, Portugal, Gibraltar and Andorra bound Spain.

definitions.definition: To be the boundary of.
A sizeable jump, great leap.
definitions.example: The deer crossed the stream in a single bound.

definitions.definition: A spring from one foot to the other in dancing.
A bounce; a rebound.
definitions.example: the bound of a ball

definitions.definition: To leap, move by jumping.
definitions.example: The rabbit bounded down the lane.

definitions.definition: To cause to leap.
definitions.example: to bound a horse

definitions.definition: To rebound; to bounce.
definitions.example: a rubber ball bounds on the floor

definitions.definition: To cause to rebound; to throw so that it will rebound; to bounce.
definitions.example: to bound a ball on the floor

definitions.definition: An alarm.
A notification of higher importance than an advisory.
A state of readiness for potential combat.
definitions.example: an airborne alert; ground alert

definitions.definition: Attentive; awake; on guard.
Brisk; nimble; moving with celerity.
To give warning to.
(rare or literary in North America) While, at the same time.
definitions.example: Drivers must switch off engines whilst on stand.

definitions.definition: To run away; to escape.
definitions.example: The prisoner tried to flee, but was caught by the guards.

definitions.definition: To escape from.
definitions.example: Many people fled the country as war loomed.

definitions.definition: To disappear quickly; to vanish.
definitions.example: Ethereal products flee once freely exposed to air.

definitions.definition: Inclination towards something; predisposition, partiality, prejudice, preference, predilection.
The diagonal line between warp and weft in a woven fabric.
A wedge-shaped piece of cloth taken out of a garment (such as the waist of a dress) to diminish its circumference.
A voltage or current applied to an electronic device, such as a transistor electrode, to move its operating point to a desired part of its transfer function.
The difference between the expectation of the sample estimator and the true population value, which reduces the representativeness of the estimator by systematically distorting it.

In the games of crown green bowls and lawn bowls: a weight added to one side of a bowl so that as it rolls, it will follow a curved rather than a straight path; the oblique line followed by such a bowl; the lopsided shape or structure of such a bowl. In lawn bowls, the curved course is caused only by the shape of the bowl. The use of weights is prohibited.
A person's favourite member of a K-pop band.
To place bias upon; to influence.
definitions.example: Our prejudices bias our views.

definitions.definition: Inclined to one side; swelled on one side.
Cut slanting or diagonally, as cloth.
In a slanting manner; crosswise; obliquely; diagonally.
definitions.example: to cut cloth bias

definitions.definition: An instance of exhibiting.
That which is exhibited.
A public showing; an exhibition.
definitions.example: The museum's new exhibit is drawing quite a crowd.

definitions.definition: An article formally introduced as evidence in a court.
definitions.example: Exhibit A is this photograph of the corpse.

definitions.definition: To display or show (something) for others to see, especially at an exhibition or contest.
definitions.example: He wanted to exhibit his baseball cards.

definitions.definition: To demonstrate.
definitions.example: The players exhibited great skill.

definitions.definition: To submit (a physical object) to a court as evidence.
definitions.example: I now exhibit this bloody hammer.

definitions.definition: To put on a public display.
definitions.example: Will you be exhibiting this year?

definitions.definition: To administer as a remedy.
definitions.example: to exhibit calomel

definitions.definition: The settlement of differences by arbitration or by consent reached by mutual concessions.
A committal to something derogatory or objectionable; a prejudicial concession; a surrender.
definitions.example: a compromise of character or right

definitions.definition: In data security, a violation of the security system such that an unauthorized disclosure or loss of sensitive information may have occurred, or the unauthorized disclosure or loss itself.
To bind by mutual agreement.
To adjust and settle by mutual concessions; to compound.
To find a way between extremes.
To pledge by some act or declaration; to endanger the life, reputation, etc., of, by some act which can not be recalled; to expose to suspicion.
To cause impairment of.
To breach (a security system).
definitions.example: He tried to compromise the security in the computer by guessing the password.

definitions.definition: A document issued by some authority, creating a public or private institution, and defining its purposes and privileges.
A similar document conferring rights and privileges on a person, corporation etc.
A contract for the commercial leasing of a vessel, or space on a vessel.
The temporary hiring or leasing of a vehicle.
A deed (legal contract).
A special privilege, immunity, or exemption.
(in a noun phrase with another noun which is either an agent or action) a provision whose unintended consequence would be to encourage an undesirable activity
definitions.example: 2005 November 30, Stephen Foley "The market where 'caveat emptor' has become a charter for fraud" The Independent, London

definitions.definition: To grant or establish a charter.
To lease or hire something by charter.
(of a peace officer) To inform (an arrestee) of their constitutional rights under the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms upon arrest.
Leased or hired.
A long, thin and flexible form of material, generally with a round cross-section, used in sewing, weaving or in the construction of string.
A continued theme or idea.
definitions.example: All of these essays have a common thread.

definitions.definition: A screw thread.
A sequence of connections.
The line midway between the banks of a stream.
A unit of execution, lighter in weight than a process, usually sharing memory and other resources with other threads executing concurrently.
A series of messages, generally grouped by subject, in which all messages except the first are replies to previous messages in the thread.
A filament, as of a flower, or of any fibrous substance, as of bark.
Composition; quality; fineness.
To put thread through.
definitions.example: thread a needle

definitions.definition: To pass (through a narrow constriction or around a series of obstacles).
definitions.example: I think I can thread my way through here, but it’s going to be tight.

definitions.definition: To screw on, to fit the threads of a nut on a bolt
A special group or social class of people which have a superior intellectual, social or economic status as, the elite of society.
Someone who is among the best at a certain task.
Of high birth or social position; aristocratic or patrician.
Representing the choicest or most select of a group.
A ceremony to honour and remember a deceased person. Often distinguished from a memorial service by the presence of the body of the deceased.
definitions.example: Many mourners turned up at the local artist's funeral to pay homage.

definitions.definition: (chiefly in the plural) A funeral sermon.
Of or relating to a funeral.
Similar to a funeral in mood; dignified or solemn.
The loose part of a coat; the lower part of a garment that plays loosely; a skirt; an apron.
An edge; a border; a hem, as of cloth.
The part of the clothing that lies on the knees or thighs when one sits down; that part of the person thus covered
A place of rearing and fostering
The upper legs of a seated person.
definitions.example: The boy was sitting on his mother's lap.

definitions.definition: The female pudenda.
A component that overlaps or covers any portion of itself or of an adjacent component.
To enfold; to hold as in one's lap; to cherish.
To rest or recline in a lap, or as in a lap.
The act or process of lapping.
That part of any substance or fixture which extends over, or lies upon, or by the side of, a part of another.
definitions.example: the lap of a board

definitions.definition: The state or condition of being in part extended over or by the side of something else; or the extent of the overlapping.
definitions.example: The second boat got a lap of half its length on the leader.

definitions.definition: The amount by which a slide valve at its half stroke overlaps a port in the seat, being equal to the distance the valve must move from its mid stroke position in order to begin to open the port. Used alone, lap refers to outside lap (see below).
One circuit around a race track, or one traversal down and then back the length of a pool
definitions.example: swim two laps

definitions.definition: In card playing and other games, the points won in excess of the number necessary to complete a game; — so called when they are counted in the score of the following game.
A sheet, layer, or bat, of cotton fiber prepared for the carding machine.

A piece of brass, lead, or other soft metal, used to hold a cutting or polishing powder in cutting glass, gems, etc. or in polishing cutlery, etc. It is usually in the form of a wheel or disk that revolves on a vertical axis.
To fold; to bend and lay over or on something.
definitions.example: to lap a piece of cloth

definitions.definition: To wrap around, enwrap, wrap up
definitions.example: to lap a bandage around a finger

definitions.definition: To envelop, enfold
definitions.example: lapped in luxury

definitions.definition: To wind around
To place or lay (one thing) so as to overlap another.
definitions.example: One laps roof tiles so that water can run off.

definitions.definition: To polish, e.g., a surface, until smooth.
To be turned or folded; to lie partly on or over something; to overlap.
definitions.example: The boats lap; the edges lap.

definitions.definition: To overtake a straggler in a race by completing one more whole lap than the straggler.
To cut or polish with a lap, as glass, gems, cutlery, etc.
To take (liquid) into the mouth with the tongue; to lick up with a quick motion of the tongue.
definitions.example: Don't lap your soup like that, you look like a dog.

definitions.definition: (of water) To wash against a surface with a splashing sound; to swash.
Of, relating to, or using laparoscopy or a laparoscope.
Examination of the loins or abdomen, now specifically examination or surgery on the peritoneal cavity using a laparoscope.
A deep chasm or abyss in the earth.
The amount swallowed in one gulp; the act of swallowing.
definitions.example: He took the aspirin with a single swallow of water.

definitions.definition: Any of various carbohydrate-based dishes that are swallowed without much chewing.
To cause (food, drink etc.) to pass from the mouth into the stomach; to take into the stomach through the throat.
To take (something) in so that it disappears; to consume, absorb.
To take food down into the stomach; to make the muscular contractions of the oesophagus to achieve this, often taken as a sign of nervousness or strong emotion.
definitions.example: My throat was so sore that I was unable to swallow.

definitions.definition: To accept easily or without questions; to believe, accept.
To engross; to appropriate; usually with up.
To retract; to recant.
definitions.example: to swallow one's opinions

definitions.definition: To put up with; to bear patiently or without retaliation.
definitions.example: to swallow an affront or insult

definitions.definition: A small, migratory bird of the Hirundinidae family with long, pointed, moon-shaped wings and a forked tail which feeds on the wing by catching insects.
The aperture in a block through which the rope reeves.
The space from the thumb to the end of the little finger when extended; nine inches; an eighth of a fathom.
(by extension) A small space or a brief portion of time.
definitions.example: He has a short attention span and gets bored within minutes.

definitions.definition: A portion of something by length; a subsequence.
The spread or extent of an arch or between its abutments, or of a beam, girder, truss, roof, bridge, or the like, between supports.
The length of a cable, wire, rope, chain between two consecutive supports.
A rope having its ends made fast so that a purchase can be hooked to the bight; also, a rope made fast in the center so that both ends can be used.
A pair of horses or other animals driven together; usually, such a pair of horses when similar in color, form, and action.
The space of all linear combinations of something.
The time required to execute a parallel algorithm on an infinite number of processors, i.e. the shortest distance across a directed acyclic graph representing the computation steps.
To extend through the distance between or across.
definitions.example: The suspension bridge spanned the canyon.

definitions.definition: To extend through (a time period).
definitions.example: The novel spans three centuries.

definitions.definition: To measure by the span of the hand with the fingers extended, or with the fingers encompassing the object.
definitions.example: to span a space or distance; to span a cylinder

definitions.definition: To generate an entire space by means of linear combinations.
To be matched, as horses.
To fetter, as a horse; to hobble.
To rotate, revolve, gyrate (usually quickly); to partially or completely rotate to face another direction.
definitions.example: I spun myself around a few times.

definitions.definition: To make yarn by twisting and winding fibers together.
definitions.example: They spin the cotton into thread.

definitions.definition: To present, describe, or interpret, or to introduce a bias or slant, so as to give something a favorable or advantageous appearance.
(of a bowler) To make the ball move sideways when it bounces on the pitch.
(of a ball) To move sideways when bouncing.
To form into thin strips or ribbons, as with sugar
To form (a web, a cocoon, silk, etc.) from threads produced by the extrusion of a viscid, transparent liquid, which hardens on coming into contact with the air; said of the spider, the silkworm, etc.
To shape, as malleable sheet metal, into a hollow form, by bending or buckling it by pressing against it with a smooth hand tool or roller while the metal revolves, as in a lathe.
To move swiftly.
definitions.example: to spin along the road in a carriage, on a bicycle, etc.

definitions.definition: To stream or issue in a thread or a small current or jet.
definitions.example: Blood spins from a vein.

definitions.definition: To wait in a loop until some condition becomes true.
To play (vinyl records, etc.) as a disc jockey.
To use an exercise bicycle, especially as part of a gym class.
An abnormal condition in journal bearings where the bearing seizes to the shaft that is rotating and rotates inside the journal, destroying both the shaft and the journal.
To have a strong desire or ambition to achieve something.
definitions.example: He aspires to become a successful doctor.

definitions.definition: To go as high as, to reach the top of (something).
To move upward; to be very tall.
To present (an argument or a plea), especially in a legal case.
definitions.example: The defendant has decided to plead not guilty.

definitions.definition: To beg, beseech, or implore.
definitions.example: He pleaded with me not to leave the house.

definitions.definition: To offer by way of excuse.
definitions.example: Not wishing to attend the banquet, I pleaded illness.

definitions.definition: To discuss by arguments.
(sometimes in the plural) The remains of a destroyed or dilapidated construction, such as a house or castle.
The state of being a ruin, destroyed or decayed.
definitions.example: The monastery has fallen into ruin.

definitions.definition: Something that leads to serious trouble or destruction.
definitions.example: Gambling has been the ruin of many.

definitions.definition: A fall or tumble.
A change that destroys or defeats something; destruction; overthrow.
definitions.example: the ruin of a ship or an army;  the ruin of a constitution or a government;  the ruin of health or hopes

definitions.definition: Complete financial loss; bankruptcy.
To cause the fiscal ruin of.
definitions.example: With all these purchases, you surely mean to ruin us!

definitions.definition: To destroy or make something no longer usable.
definitions.example: He ruined his new white slacks by accidentally spilling oil on them.

definitions.definition: To cause severe financial loss to; to bankrupt or drive out of business.
definitions.example: The crooked stockbroker's fraudulent scheme ruined dozens of victims; some investors lost their life savings and even their houses.

definitions.definition: To upset or overturn the plans or progress of, or to have a disastrous effect on something.
definitions.example: My car breaking down just as I was on the road ruined my vacation.

definitions.definition: To make something less enjoyable or likeable.
definitions.example: I used to love that song, but being assaulted when that song was playing ruined the song for me.

definitions.definition: To reveal the ending of (a story); to spoil.
To fall into a state of decay.
To seduce or debauch, and thus harm the social standing of.
definitions.example: The young libertine was notorious for ruining local girls.

definitions.definition: A person who practices a profession or art, especially law or medicine.
One who does anything customarily or habitually.
A sly or artful person.
A person whom a church or another religious group has officially recognised as especially holy or godly; one eminent for piety and virtue.
definitions.example: Kateri Tekakwitha was proclaimed a saint.

definitions.definition: (by extension) A person with positive qualities; one who does good.
definitions.example: Dorothy Day was a living saint.

definitions.definition: One of the blessed in heaven.
A holy object.
To canonize, to formally recognize someone as a saint.
definitions.example: Many wish to see Pope John Paul II sainted immediately.

definitions.definition: An activity or task with which one occupies oneself; usually specifically the productive activity, service, trade, or craft for which one is regularly paid; a job.
The act, process or state of possessing a place.
The control of a country or region by a hostile army.
To order (a drug or medical device) for use by a particular patient (under licensed authority).
definitions.example: The doctor prescribed aspirin.

definitions.definition: To specify by writing as a required procedure or ritual; to lay down authoritatively as a guide, direction, or rule of action.
definitions.example: The property meets the criteria prescribed by the regulations.

definitions.definition: The act of collaborating.
definitions.example: Collaboration can be a useful part of the creative process.

definitions.definition: A production or creation made by collaborating.
definitions.example: The husband-and-wife artists will release their new collaboration in June this year.

definitions.definition: Treasonous cooperation.
definitions.example: He has been charged with collaboration.

definitions.definition: The act of examining something, often closely.
definitions.example: Upon closer inspection, the animal turned out to be a dolphin, not a shark!

definitions.definition: An organization that checks that certain laws or rules are obeyed.
definitions.example: The inspection fined the restaurant's owner because the kitchen was dirty.

definitions.definition: The state or condition of being useful; usefulness.
Something that is useful.
The ability of a commodity to satisfy needs or wants; the satisfaction experienced by the consumer of that commodity.
Well-being, satisfaction, pleasure, or happiness.
A service provider, such as an electric company or water company; or, the securities of such a provider.
A software program designed to perform a single task or a small range of tasks, often to help manage and tune computer hardware, an operating system or application software.
definitions.example: I've bought a new disk utility that can recover deleted files.

definitions.definition: The ability to play multiple positions.
Having to do with, or owned by, a service provider.
definitions.example: utility line; utility bill

definitions.definition: Designating of a room in a house or building where mechanical equipment is installed; such as a furnace, water tank/heater, circuit breaker, and/or air conditioning unit; and often equipped with hookups for laundry equipment (washer/dryer).
definitions.example: utility room

definitions.definition: A period of unusually low rainfall, longer and more severe than a dry spell.
(by extension) A longer than expected term without success, particularly in sport.
To steal from, especially using force or violence.
definitions.example: He robbed three banks before he was caught.

definitions.definition: To deprive of, or withhold from, unjustly or injuriously; to defraud.
definitions.example: The best way to rob a bank is to own one.

definitions.definition: (used with "of") To deprive (of).
definitions.example: Working all day robs me of any energy to go out in the evening.

definitions.definition: To burgle.
To steal.
definitions.example: That chav robbed my phone!

definitions.definition: To commit robbery.
To take possession of the ball, puck etc. from.
The inspissated juice of ripe fruit, obtained by evaporation of the juice over a fire until it reaches a syrupy consistency. It is sometimes mixed with honey or sugar.
A number representing a comparison between two named things.
The relative magnitudes of two quantities (usually expressed as a quotient).
Short for ratio decidendi.
The amount of comments to a post or other expression on social media relative to the number of likes.
(social media) To respond to a post or message on social media in a greater number than the number of likes the post receives.
definitions.example: The schoolchildren ganged up to ratio the school catering over its shamefully undemocratic inclusion of vegetables in meals.

definitions.definition: A district represented by one or more elected officials.
definitions.example: John was elected to parliament from the Bedford constituency.

definitions.definition: (collective) The voters within such a district.
(collective) The residents of such a district.
(collective) The voters of a candidate.
An interest group or fan base.
A group of people organized for some common purpose, usually of about ten members.
One's friend group, taken collectively; one's peeps.
To act as part of, or on behalf of, a squad.
definitions.example: We squad on the fifth of the month.

definitions.definition: Sloppy mud.
To oversee or direct a task or organization.
definitions.example: Without someone to supervise them, the group will lack direction.

definitions.definition: To look over so as to read; to peruse.
A slashing action or motion, particularly:
A mark made by a slashing motion, particularly:
Something resembling such a mark, particularly:
The loose woody debris remaining from a slash, (particularly forestry) the trimmings left while preparing felled trees for removal.
definitions.example: Slash generated during logging may constitute a fire hazard.

definitions.definition: Slash fiction.
To cut or attempt to cut, particularly:
To strike violently and randomly, particularly:
To move quickly and violently.
To crack a whip with a slashing motion.
To clear land, (particularly forestry) with violent action such as logging or brushfires or through grazing.
definitions.example: The province's traditional slash-and-burn agriculture was only sustainable with a much smaller population.

definitions.definition: To write slash fiction.
Used to note the sound or action of a slash.
Used to connect two or more identities in a list.
Used to list alternatives.
A drink of something; a draft.
A piss: an act of urination.
To piss, to urinate.
A swampy area; a swamp.
A large quantity of watery food such as broth.
To work in wet conditions.
The period of a transitory breeze.
An interval of good weather.
The loose part of a rope; slack.
A reminder or cue.
A time limit given for payment of an account for produce purchased, this limit varying with different goods.
A sequence of characters that appears on a monitor to indicate that the computer is ready to receive input.
definitions.example: I filled in my name where the prompt appeared on the computer screen but my account wasn't recognized.

definitions.definition: (writing) A suggestion for inspiration given to an author.
To lead (someone) toward what they should say or do.
definitions.example: I prompted him to get a new job.

definitions.definition: To show or tell an actor/person the words they should be saying, or actions they should be doing.
definitions.example: If he forgets his words I will prompt him.

definitions.definition: To initiate; to cause or lead to.
Quick; acting without delay.
definitions.example: He was very prompt at getting a new job.

definitions.definition: On time; punctual.
definitions.example: Be prompt for your appointment.

definitions.definition: Ready; willing to act.
The ability to read and write.
Understanding of something (ex. computer literacy).
To raise (something) to a higher position.
definitions.example: The doctor told me elevating my legs would help reduce the swelling.

definitions.definition: To promote (someone) to a higher rank.
To confer honor or nobility on (someone).
definitions.example: The traditional worldview elevates man as the pinnacle of creation.

definitions.definition: To make (something or someone) more worthy or of greater value.
definitions.example: A talented chef can elevate everyday ingredients into gourmet delights.

definitions.definition: To direct (the mind, thoughts, etc.) toward more worthy things.
To increase the intensity or degree of (something).
definitions.example: Some drugs have the side effect of elevating your blood sugar level.

definitions.definition: To lift the spirits of (someone)
To intoxicate in a slight degree; to make (someone) tipsy.
(Latinism) To attempt to make (something) seem less important, remarkable, etc.
Elevated; raised aloft.
A metric unit of mass equal to 1000 kilograms. Symbol: t
A score of 100.
Pleasing, encouraging or approving.
definitions.example: The candidate wearing the business suite made a favourable impression.

definitions.definition: Useful or helpful.
definitions.example: We made quick progress, due to favourable winds.

definitions.definition: Convenient or at a suitable time; opportune.
definitions.example: The rain stopped at a favourable time for our tennis match.

definitions.definition: Auspicious or lucky.
definitions.example: She says that she was born under a favourable star.

definitions.definition: An act of stabbing or thrusting with an object.
A wound made by stabbing.
Pain inflicted on a person's feelings.
An attempt.
Criticism.
A single staccato chord that adds dramatic impact to a composition.
definitions.example: a horn stab

definitions.definition: A bacterial culture made by inoculating a solid medium, such as gelatin, with the puncture of a needle or wire.
To pierce or to wound (somebody) with a pointed tool or weapon, especially a knife or dagger.
definitions.example: If you stab him in the heart he won't live long enough to retaliate.

definitions.definition: To thrust in a stabbing motion.
definitions.example: to stab a dagger into a person

definitions.definition: To recklessly hit with the tip of a pointed object, such as a weapon or finger (often used with at).
definitions.example: He stabbed at my face with the twig but luckily kept missing my eyes.

definitions.definition: To cause a sharp, painful sensation (often used with at).
definitions.example: The snow from the blizzard was stabbing at my face as I skied down the mountain.

definitions.definition: To injure secretly or by malicious falsehood or slander.
definitions.example: to stab a person's reputation

definitions.definition: To roughen a brick wall with a pick so as to hold plaster.
To pierce folded sheets, near their back edges, for the passage of thread or wire.
To give up; to relinquish ownership of.
To hand over (something to someone), place into the care or control of another.
To quit (a job or position).
definitions.example: He resigned the crown to follow his heart.

definitions.definition: To submit passively; to give up as hopeless or inevitable.
definitions.example: After fighting for so long, she finally resigned to her death.

definitions.definition: To sign again; to provide one's signature again.
(by extension) To sign a contract renewing or restarting a professional relationship, such as that of a professional athlete with a sports team.
